comments.commentBody:
The last time I caught part of the show, he had his nose on top of the mic and you could hear him breathing heavily the entire time the cast was performing a skit. Then he started whistling his s's as he spoke, like an old timey affectation. I used to listen occasionally because they sometimes had great musical guests on the show. But once he started deliberately making the geezer noises, I stopped listening.
Still, I will never forget my favorite Keillor joke from years ago: "George Bush says he wants to put a man on the moon. (Perfect pause) So do I."

Interesting questions - I suspect it is because of the dilemma of how labeling relates to the story: Does it matter? If so, why? Is it necessary or just incidental? A "straight" club wouldn't be so-labeled. Labeling a club as gay at one time would be used solely to titillate the public, as clickbait - offensive.

Once it was suspected that this was a reason these people were targeted, it was a part of the story. My guess.

That's what I came to this story looking for: An explanation of how this important information was left out for as long as it was. Certainly any story grows in accuracy as reports comes in, but it was easily knowable that Pulse was a gay club. The initial omission becomes part of the story because of tendency to erase the LGBT aspect in favor of a more mainstream narrative.
It's a decent theory Cheryl but the answe should have been kart of this story.

You should discuss why your initial story dId not describe Pulse as a gay club and instead stated that the club billed itself as having a Latin night. This omission continued well after most news sites were referring to the fact that the club clearly and readily bills itself as a gay club on its home page on FB. I found the omission very odd. Would like to hear the reasoning

"Kaiser Permanente, Intermountain Healthcare, the Mayo Clinic and Geisinger Health System are some of the integrated delivery systems with reputations for high quality and low costs."

Maybe there should be closer study of why integrated care works in some places.

Sounds a little familiar, a bunch of states with different views of a federal organization. Brexit may be a tonic for a bureaucratic structure in need of a little more democracy.

But Britain will be the loser in a Brexit vote, strengthening Germany and France while diminishing their global role.

Let's hope the British people send a message through a close vote that the EU model needs reform, not dissolution.

Glad to see this type of classic modus operandi from China is now finally widely published in the international press. All Taiwanese young and old are used to seeing this type of petty shenanigans from China, whether it be government officials or civilian. Have you heard of the one where an entire busload of Chinese basketball team forfeiting a game because en route to a collegiate game they saw Taiwanese flags flying? What about the time when Chinese journalists stormed the stage of a video game championship because the Taiwanese kids were waving Taiwanese flags. Then there's the educators that walked out of an international conference because their Taiwanese counterparts were using Taiwan on their name cards. What about the Chinese students protesting the inclusion of Team Taiwan in Harvard's Model UN? Don't forget the Chinese diplomat that protested to the state department because some Oregon restaurant painted a pro Taiwan mural. My trip to the zoo is interrupted to report graffiti drawing in Taiwan as part of China on a map next to the panda exhibit. When traveling I had to call to get a travel site to change the silly "Chinese Taipei" to Taiwan. I even had to endure staredowns from the Chinese booth in my kid's elementary school multicultural night.

The above is the essence of being Taiwanese, and it just makes us more adamant of our Taiwanese identity. And these 50 kids will be no different, their Taiwanese identity is now solidly engraved in their hearts and minds.
Yes, but with great relative difficulty in Britain unlike the US. And certainly not the ease with which one can buy assault rifles in this country such as the one used in Orlando.
But we'd prefer one incident a decade rather than several a day

The US abstained in a vote on "HRC 29: Human Rights and the Regulation of Civilian Acquisition, Possession and Use of Firearms".

The US statement said, in part: "We do not believe that a State’s regulation of the purely domestic acquisition, possession, and use of firearms is an appropriate topic for international attention generally or the Human Rights Council specifically. Further, we do not regard the domestic actions suggested by this resolution to be required by international human rights obligations. And we do not interpret this resolution as giving any international body or its representatives a voice in the domestic regulation of firearms."

http://www.humanrights.gov/dyn/2015/06/hrc-29-human-rights-and-the-regul...

“My brother is not violent and is not all that political. I don’t even know who he votes for. He has a history of mental illness, but he has had help,” the newspaper quoted him as saying.

There...you some how forgot that quote.

From an Agence France-Presse release: The attacker was named by British media as local man Tommy Mair, with neighbours quoted as saying he was a "loner" who kept to himself.

The Southern Poverty Law Center said he was a supporter of a neo-Nazi group based in the United States and had what it called a long history with white nationalism.

"According to records obtained by the Southern Poverty Law Center Mair was a dedicated supporter of the National Alliance (NA), the once premier neo-Nazi organization in the United States, for decades," the US-based legal advocacy group said on its website.

The group said he had spent more than $620 on reading material from the National Alliance, a group which called for the creation of an all-white homeland and eradication of Jewish people.

This assassination is totally irrational in all respects.  Violent extremists have no effective voice among civilized political movements.  It should be totally up to the British people whether there is sufficient will to break away from the EU or not.  Give the political process time to cool so that such a senseless killing will have zero effect on the outcome of the impending vote.
Everything about the AR-15 design is aimed at making it easy for the shooter to sustain a steady rate of fire.

I recall the Tucson shooting of Rep. Giffords. In that attack a Glock 19 semi-automatic with a 33-round magazine, easily purchased at your corner gun shop was used. The tragedy in Leeds was tempered and did not result in a wholesale slaughter due to limitations on weapons for purchase in Britain. We need stricter gun laws in the U.S. Not all shootings can be prevented, but they can be reduced and limited in damage. Orlando, Sandy Hook, San Bernadino and the others would have had fewer deaths without the AR-15 type killing machines used, also readily available for purchase.

This argument from the pro-gun side that "people can get guns even if you ban them so what's the point in banning them" is plain stupid. People will still commit murder even though it's banned. People will still get Heroin and other illegal substances, objects, services even though they are banned. Laws will always be broken, but clearly that shouldn't mean that we just don't bother having laws. Having them is ultimately better for society than not.

It may be a valid point that even in countries where gun ownership is outlawed people can still find a way to get a gun. It's also very clear from widely available statistics that the U.S. has many, many more mass shootings than any other advanced country where guns are banned, even when the population difference is accounted for.

This implies that if the U.S. make it more difficult for people to own guns there would be much fewer mass shootings. It's not complicated, it would save more lives and prevent more tragedies.
Sort of tough not to see the assassination of a politician in political terms.

Mr.Ranson, a Labor or Labour party member need not be a Socialist. There is actually several Socialist parties in England, and they have some representation, but few. Labor or Labour (the American spelling versus the British spelling) is pro labor, not socialist. I don't know if you miswrote, or are genuinely against Socialists or something. It is getting tiring in the US to have people mix up Socialist policies with Socialism with Communism.  It is like people mistaking capitalism with fascism. Would you like that? Kindly use proper definitions. There is an actual Socialist Party of England and Wales.

"I'm Australian so I understand the British character a little better than most Americans, who don't quite understand how what happens in the States affects what happens in the world around them."

Coming from someone who insinuates that anyone expressing sentiments (skepticism toward one or another overarching super national organism, or toward the salutary nature of Third World immigration) which may be amalgamated to nationalism, the rampant chauvinism in the above statement is more than a little ironic.
We give faith-based beliefs more credit than they are due too.

The answer is that it's not "irredeemable."  Our enlightened society is not a platonic ideal; it's more like a living organism, say a human body.  The groups you describe are viruses.  They can and do release toxins and cause symptoms; some are curable, while others are chronic; and our societal immune system works to keep them all in check.  But writing off western society on that basis would be like writing off your aunt when she gets a cold.

The next time we dismiss the recurring theme from Islamic extremists that western society, especially the United States, is irredeemably corrupt and evil, please explain to all of us how our "enlightened" society continues to be a fertile breeding ground for homegrown hate groups like the National Alliiance.

I'm a Kiwi and whole-heartedly agree with Colin. The filth being spewed out of the US by Donald Trump's hate speech is affecting the whole English speaking world. The American people should stand up against it, particularly those Republicans who are not speaking out about the evil he represents. My thoughts go to Ms Cox's family at this terrible time. She obviously was a very decent person. As for Dom's comment that the vehicles for much of Trump's invective are owned by Rupert Murdoch, Australian born billionaire, that's true, but he is now a US citizen, a financial migrant. I used to work for Murdoch in Australia in the 1960s. His womanizing amoral future was  emerging then.  Murdoch's just another (albeit more successful) Donald Trump, a man who flew on his father's coat tails. The difference is that Sir Keith Murdoch, his father, would be ashamed of him.

Because a single isolated act of gun violence proves unequivocally that gun control doesn't work, right? If the NYT comments section allowed emojis, there would be about 10 eye-rolls at the end of this.

Very few senators or congressmen have government paid bodyguards like the secret service. The ones that do have either been directly threatened, in line to become president in an emergency, or maybe ranking leadership.

I know in my state the governor has some state troopers that escort him and provide transportation.
The evidence that the killer did this for any motive other than insanity is quite thin.
One of the witnesses to that has recanted their story. A person who was actually wrestling the killer to the ground said he heard mumbling but nothing clear.

Is this comment satire? The most overwhelming oaf in American politics today, Donald trump, and American culture (whom even the political American Right hates, despite being the republican nominee) is to blame for this? Is there not one single issue which people would not pin to the United States?

I wonder, would you also blame the unspeakably barbaric philosophies of the middle eat and North Africa for terrorism in the west? Or is that also the cause of American (admittedly, unprincipled, insane, "pragmatic") policy and culture as well?

UK has some of the toughest gun control laws in the world. There is no 'gun culture' there. Or even in the US for the matter. Violent crimes like these are extremely rare and we shouldn't speculate until we get all the details. Indian MPs and MLAs have been killed by guns too, much more frequently than in Britain. Do you think India has a gun culture too?

FAIL-since when do we reward a neo nazi's action with a curtailing and constricting of the human experience which is a shared empathy -it is critical that we honor this person with tolerance and an expansive humanist agrnda

Just the opposite of what Jo Cox believed in and campaigned for all her life.  Her husband expressed her wish that we unite against the hatred that killed her, not embrace it.  Congratulations on missing the point entirely.
A rather irrelevant point to make given that the shooter in this case wasn't, in fact, an immigrant.

There are huge benefits, and today is as good a day as any, to severely restricting all international immigration between all countries for a few generations in order to allow for cultural assimilation by country.

So you can pick two alternate realities

1) The gunman had a military style assault rifle with unlimited ammunition and slaughtered half the neighbourhood before being shot dead by 50 police officers in a hours long siege on live tv.

2) The gunman had a single shot hunting rifle or shotgun and was taken down by two unarmed police officers to be interrogated to find out what other idiots if any he had help from.

It's a democracy so you get to choose the reality you live in. I know which one I choose.
